comments.content:
Synchronization - Data synchronization is the ongoing process of synchronizing data between two or more devices and updating changes automatically between them to maintain consistency within systems. 
source: https://www.google.com/search?q=synchronization+in+cloud+computing&rlz=1C1CHBF_enCA896CA896&oq=synchronization+in+Cload&aqs=chrome.1.69i57j0i13j0i5i13i30l4j0i8i13i30.10152j1j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 
Searched in other websites too, Synchronization is also their answer.

C is correct answer.

Resource pooling is an IT term used in cloud computing environments to describe a situation in which providers serve multiple clients, customers or "tenants" with provisional and scalable services. These services can be adjusted to suit each client's needs without any changes being apparent to the client or end user.

questions.question_text: Which of the following explains how a cloud computing provider is able to provide scalable services to several different clients?

During an inspection, it was found that data racks were not properly grounded. To pass the inspection and address a growing concern to protect data cabling and equipment, a technician must make sure all racks are properly grounded.
Which of the following tools should the technician use to verify this has been completed?

discussion.content:
Explanation
A multimeter has the ability to measure the voltage, amperage, and resistance of a circuit. If you use the lowest ohms (resistance) setting, you can touch the multimeter's black lead to a grounded metal surface and touch the red lead to each wire of the circuit. If you get a meter reading of zero ohms (low resistance), then this indicates that the circuit is properly grounded. If you get a meter reading of infinity, O.L., Open Loop, or a needle that pegs high on the meter, this indicates an open circuit with no path to ground.

From Jason Dion's Udemy practice exams

questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a new workstation. The technician wants to make sure the workstation will not load the OS if a portable hard drive is connected to it.
Which of the following should the technician configure?

discussion.content: Legacy mode will prevent hard drives that are not in the boot list from working and the workstation will not load. Secure boot is part of UEFI bios and it will work if we use UEFI which has secure boot. So we must choose Legacy mode to prevent a portable hard drive from working.

comments.content: Thanks for the explanation. This really doesn't make sense at first glance

discussion.content: I chose secure boot because it makes sense. But ok.

Seems like abit of a crappy question since both Secure Boot and Legacy mode are apparently correct. Had to google to figure out what Legacy mode actually is, but according to that if USB Legacy Support is disabled then the computer may not boot correctly when external hard drives are connected. Seems abit silly though that that would be the answer CompTIA wants instead of Secure Boot which is something that has actually been covered in the course material.

https://smallbusiness.chron.com/computer-wont-boot-up-external-usb-hard-drive-attached-80463.html
but why does it sat Legacy?

questions.question_text: A technician is deploying a wireless access point for streaming 4K videos and online gaming. Which of the following wireless frequencies is MOST appropriate in this scenario?
A technician installed a new scanner and imaging camera on a desktop to upload high-resolution images into an electronic health records application. This application is am example of:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Because On-Demand allows agents to do one or more of the following, depending on permissions and configuration: start/stop audio recording, start/stop desktop recording, apply blackouts to recordings, and update call records. This topic explains how to install the On-Demand client application on a workstation.

Selected Answer: C
This indicates that the application is a thick client. A thick client refers to a software application that is installed and executed on a local desktop or workstation, where most of the processing occurs locally.

Selected Answer: D
It's An on-demand client (D).
On-Demand allows agents to do one or more of the following, depending on permissions and configuration: start/stop audio recording, start/stop desktop recording, apply blackouts to recordings, and update call records. This topic explains how to install the On-Demand client application on a workstation.

comments.content: Out of all the options, I think virtual client makes more sense than the others...

discussion.content: I think they are trying to say that it is a virtual client because the Application is the virtual client making a request to the user's computer for data in the form of copies of hard document files. The user inputs the data into their computer and their computer serves the virtual client the response via the application's user interface. That is my best answer I can think of.

this could be D.
